page.title: 18S.S.S.I.
page.content: The stretch of the River Conon in our Domesday Area has been designated a Site of Special Scientific Interest. Throughout the year there is a wide variety of ducks and waders in the stretch of river.In the spring and summer mergansers,mallard,shellduck and teal nest on the banks aswell as oyster catchers,lapwings,greenshank and curlew.Herons are a common site feeding in the shallow pools,as are woodcock,snipe and dippers.There is a huge variety of flowers growing all along the river bank and the yellow coneflower which blooms in late summer provides a spectacular scene of tall vivid yellow flowers.Butterflies and moths are also present in abundance. Seals are a common site in the lower reaches of the river as they pursue the migrating sea trout and salmon as they make there way up river.
